articles.headline: This Deal Is Encouraging and Absurd
articles.snippet: Lenders and workers are taking the risks in the Tribune Company deal, but most of the benefits will go to Sam Zell.
articles.abstract: Lenders and workers are taking the risks in the Tribune Company deal, but most of the benefits will go to Sam Zell.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS is a tale of two markets. One has unbridled optimism and believes that risk is a thing of the past. The other has experienced severe losses and can think of no reason those losses will not become worse.

articles.headline: An S O S for 911 Systems in Age of High-Tech
articles.snippet: The 911 system has not kept pace with the nation’s rapidly changing communication habits.
articles.abstract: The 911 system has not kept pace with the nation’s rapidly changing communication habits.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAHLEQUAH, Okla. — As in many areas of the country, more 911 calls here come from cellphones than land lines. But 40 percent of the nation’s counties, most of them rural or small-town communities like this one, cannot yet pinpoint the location of cellphone callers, though the technology to do so has been available for at least five years.

articles.headline: Zell Gets Veto Power at Tribune
articles.snippet: Although Samuel Zell will control a minority of the Tribune Company board, he will have the right to veto any major transactions.
articles.abstract: Although Samuel Zell will control a minority of the Tribune Company board, he will have the right to veto any major transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company last night disclosed new details of its plan to go private in a complex deal engineered by the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell, including provisions that will give Mr. Zell broad authority over corporate activities.

articles.headline: Makers of Artificial Sweeteners Go to Court
articles.snippet: Equal and Splenda are going to court over the meaning of the phrase “made from sugar.”
articles.abstract: Equal and Splenda are going to court over the meaning of the phrase “made from sugar.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Sweetness is about to be the subject of a bitter courtroom fight.

articles.headline: Again, Kerkorian Makes a Move for Chrysler
articles.snippet: After failing in one takeover in the 1990s, the billionaire has returned with a $4.5 billion bid for the automaker.
articles.abstract: After failing in one takeover in the 1990s, the billionaire has returned with a $4.5 billion bid for the automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kirk Kerkorian is back. After making billions on brazen investments in Hollywood, Las Vegas and Detroit, he is now pursuing Chrysler once more, a dozen years after his last attempt.

articles.headline: New Urgency in Debating Health Care
articles.snippet: Many executives of large companies are starting to call for a national approach to fixing health care, warning that an employer-subsidized health system is unsustainable.
articles.abstract: Many executives of large companies are starting to call for a national approach to fixing health care, warning that an employer-subsidized health system is unsustainable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Hillary Rodham Clinton’s effort to overhaul the nation’s medical system was rejected in 1994, most big employers have stayed out of the debate on health care reform.

articles.headline: To Fortify China, Soybean Harvest Grows in Brazil
articles.snippet: Diminishing cropland and water supplies are pushing China to seek more of its staples from South America.
articles.abstract: Diminishing cropland and water supplies are pushing China to seek more of its staples from South America.
articles.lead_paragraph: RONDONÓPOLIS, Brazil — For more than 2,000 years, the Chinese have turned soybeans into tofu, a staple of the country’s diet.

articles.headline: Dutch Soldiers Stress Restraint in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The tactics of the task force emphasize efforts to improve living conditions and self-governance.
articles.abstract: The tactics of the task force emphasize efforts to improve living conditions and self-governance.
articles.lead_paragraph: QALA-E-SURKH, Afghanistan — The Dutch infantrymen stood on a ridge near the Baluchi Valley, an area in south-central Afghanistan controlled by the Taliban and tribes opposed to the central government.
